<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The coordination of the ligand 5,6,7-trimethyl-[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>]pyrimidine towards transition-metal ions is strongly dependent on the counter ion.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A variety of new coordination compounds with transition-metal salts and the ligand trimethyl[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>]pyrimidine (abbreviated as tmtp) is described, together with several of their 3D crystal structures and spectroscopic and magnetic properties. The compounds were selected based on the coordination ability of the counterion, halide, nitrate, sulfate, thiocyanate and perchlorate. The formed coordination compounds and their coordination numbers were found to be strongly dependent on both the cation and the used counter-anion. The several compounds studied have the following structural formulae: [CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [CuBr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [ZnBr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [CuSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(MeOH), [Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [Zn(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [Cd(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and [M(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, in which M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, Ni, Zn.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The coordination of the ligand 5,6,7-trimethyl-[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidine towards transition-metal ions is strongly dependent on the counter ion.

Abstract

A variety of new coordination compounds with transition-metal salts and the ligand trimethyl[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidine (abbreviated as tmtp) is described, together with several of their 3D crystal structures and spectroscopic and magnetic properties. The compounds were selected based on the coordination ability of the counterion, halide, nitrate, sulfate, thiocyanate and perchlorate. The formed coordination compounds and their coordination numbers were found to be strongly dependent on both the cation and the used counter-anion. The several compounds studied have the following structural formulae: [CuCl2(tmtp)2], [CuBr2(tmtp)2], [ZnBr2(tmtp)2], [Cu(NO3)2(tmtp)2], [CuSO4(tmtp)2]2(H2O)(MeOH), [Cu(H2O)(NCS)2(tmtp)2], [Zn(NCS)2(tmtp)2], [Cd(NCS)2(tmtp)2] and [M(H2O)2(tmtp)4](BF4)2, in which M=Co, Ni, Zn.

<ce:simple-para view="all">The new coordination compounds have been further characterized by NMR, (far-)IR and LF spectra, as well as by C, H, N element analyses, and EPR spectra for the Cu(II) compounds. The coordination around the metal varies from <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (Zn, Cu), via <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> (Cu) to <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> (for Co, Cu and Cd). The anions usually complete the coordination sphere; only the Co and Zn compounds with the tetrafluoridoborate anions have no coordinated anions, but water ligands complete the octahedral coordination sphere. In the 5-coordinated [Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] water completes the square pyramid geometry.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: The new coordination compounds have been further characterized by NMR, (far-)IR and LF spectra, as well as by C, H, N element analyses, and EPR spectra for the Cu(II) compounds. The coordination around the metal varies from 4 (Zn, Cu), via 5 (Cu) to 6 (for Co, Cu and Cd). The anions usually complete the coordination sphere; only the Co and Zn compounds with the tetrafluoridoborate anions have no coordinated anions, but water ligands complete the octahedral coordination sphere. In the 5-coordinated [Cu(H2O)(NCS)2(tmtp)2] water completes the square pyramid geometry.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Triazolopyrimidines (traditional IUPAC name: [1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>]pyrimidines) are versatile ligands, as they have several nitrogen atoms with accessible lone pairs to bind to Lewis acids like metal ions, see the structure in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>, with the actual IUPAC ring numbering.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Triazolopyrimidines (traditional IUPAC name: [1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidines) are versatile ligands, as they have several nitrogen atoms with accessible lone pairs to bind to Lewis acids like metal ions, see the structure in  , with the actual IUPAC ring numbering.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">These ligands contain fused 5-membered and 6-membered rings and as such resemble the nucleobases adenine and guanine of DNA. A variety of coordination compounds of metals salts with the parent ligand and other triazoles is already known and reviewed . Previous work from this laboratory has mainly been focusing on symmetric, and methyl substituted tp-based ligands . Also other groups have been studying this type of ligands . Triazoles and pyrimidines may act as bridging ligands between metals, but may also coordinate monodentately .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: These ligands contain fused 5-membered and 6-membered rings and as such resemble the nucleobases adenine and guanine of DNA. A variety of coordination compounds of metals salts with the parent ligand and other triazoles is already known and reviewed . Previous work from this laboratory has mainly been focusing on symmetric, and methyl substituted tp-based ligands . Also other groups have been studying this type of ligands . Triazoles and pyrimidines may act as bridging ligands between metals, but may also coordinate monodentately .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In a recent paper  we reported on transition-metal compounds with the ligands (5,7-diethyl[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>]pyrimidine) and (5-methyl,7-phenyl[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>]pyrimidine). The steric effects of substituents in these ligands are interesting and have not been explored before in great detail. Therefore in the present study the ligand tmtp was selected, which has three methyl substituents on the 5, 6 and 7 position (ligand abbreviation tmtp), by studying a variety of reactions with transition-metal(II) salts, with a focus upon both the metal and the different anions. Given the fact that N1 and N4 have bulky methyl groups nearby, coordination at N3 would be expected for steric reasons, whereas the other nitrogens might be more accessible for H-bond acceptance. Still a ligand bridging two metal ions via additional coordination by N1 or N4 cannot be excluded a priory. A selection of 11 different compounds were synthesised and characterized of which 10 delivered crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In a recent paper  we reported on transition-metal compounds with the ligands (5,7-diethyl[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidine) and (5-methyl,7-phenyl[1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-a]pyrimidine). The steric effects of substituents in these ligands are interesting and have not been explored before in great detail. Therefore in the present study the ligand tmtp was selected, which has three methyl substituents on the 5, 6 and 7 position (ligand abbreviation tmtp), by studying a variety of reactions with transition-metal(II) salts, with a focus upon both the metal and the different anions. Given the fact that N1 and N4 have bulky methyl groups nearby, coordination at N3 would be expected for steric reasons, whereas the other nitrogens might be more accessible for H-bond acceptance. Still a ligand bridging two metal ions via additional coordination by N1 or N4 cannot be excluded a priory. A selection of 11 different compounds were synthesised and characterized of which 10 delivered crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray analysis.

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Starting materials</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Hydrated metal salts, solvents, diketones and 5-amino-1,2,4-triazole were used as commercially available, without further purification.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The synthesis of the ligand tmtp was carried out by a known condensation procedure  at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, from a diketone and 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole schematically as summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch2"></ce:float-anchor>, followed by recrystallization using ethanol. Observed yields were 60–70% depending on small variations in the conditions. Characterisation of the free ligand was done by elemental analysis, IR and NMR spectroscopy.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Starting materials

Hydrated metal salts, solvents, diketones and 5-amino-1,2,4-triazole were used as commercially available, without further purification.

Synthesis of the ligand

The synthesis of the ligand tmtp was carried out by a known condensation procedure  at 160°C, from a diketone and 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole schematically as summarized in  , followed by recrystallization using ethanol. Observed yields were 60-70% depending on small variations in the conditions. Characterisation of the free ligand was done by elemental analysis, IR and NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of the coordination compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The coordination compounds were prepared by the following general recipes:</ce:para><ce:para view="all">A solution of 1–2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol of the metal salt in 10–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water was added to a warm aqueous solution of the ligand (1–5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Upon standing at room temperature crystals appeared, which were collected by filtration. In some cases, MeOH/water or pure MeOH were used as a solvent. To prepare the thiocyanate compounds a metathesis reaction was used, starting from the aqueous metal nitrate and ammonium thiocyanate (1:2). Yields were found to be between 30% and 60% depending on the metal and anion. Satisfactory elemental analysis was obtained for all compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the coordination compounds

The coordination compounds were prepared by the following general recipes:

A solution of 1-2mmol of the metal salt in 10-20mL water was added to a warm aqueous solution of the ligand (1-5mmol). Upon standing at room temperature crystals appeared, which were collected by filtration. In some cases, MeOH/water or pure MeOH were used as a solvent. To prepare the thiocyanate compounds a metathesis reaction was used, starting from the aqueous metal nitrate and ammonium thiocyanate (1:2). Yields were found to be between 30% and 60% depending on the metal and anion. Satisfactory elemental analysis was obtained for all compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Physical and analytical methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">C, H, N determinations were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II analyzer. Ligand field spectra in the 300–2000 nm range were obtained on a PerkinElmer Lambda 900 spectrophotometer using the diffuse reflectance technique, using MgO as a reference. Infrared spectra of all compounds were recorded on a PerkinElmer Paragon 1000 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Golden Gate ATR device, using the reflectance technique (4000–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, res. 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). (Far-)FTIR spectra were obtained on a Bruker IFS 113v infrared spectrophotometer as polyethylene mulls (600–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, Mylar 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ, res. 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). X-band powder EPR spectra were obtained on a Bruker EMX<ce:italic>plus</ce:italic> electron spin resonance spectrometer (field calibrated with DPPH (<ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.0036)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Physical and analytical methods

C, H, N determinations were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II analyzer. Ligand field spectra in the 300-2000 nm range were obtained on a PerkinElmer Lambda 900 spectrophotometer using the diffuse reflectance technique, using MgO as a reference. Infrared spectra of all compounds were recorded on a PerkinElmer Paragon 1000 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Golden Gate ATR device, using the reflectance technique (4000-300cm-1, res. 4cm-1). (Far-)FTIR spectra were obtained on a Bruker IFS 113v infrared spectrophotometer as polyethylene mulls (600-100cm-1, Mylar 6μ, res. 2cm-1). X-band powder EPR spectra were obtained on a Bruker EMXplus electron spin resonance spectrometer (field calibrated with DPPH (g =2.0036)).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray diffraction studies</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">For each coordination compound a suitable crystal was selected from the mother liquid and mounted to a glass fiber using the oil-drop method. Diffraction data were collected on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation). The structures were solved by direct methods. The programs <ce:small-caps>collect</ce:small-caps>
, <ce:small-caps>shelxs-97</ce:small-caps>
, <ce:small-caps>shelxl-97</ce:small-caps>
 were used for data reduction, structure solution and structure refinement, respectively. Refinement of <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> was performed against all reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The water Hydrogen atoms of compounds <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> were picked from difference maps and refined isotropically. All other H-atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. Details of compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>: one of the two methanol molecules and the water molecule were found to be severely disordered. The methanol C7 and the water O9 were each refined with an occupancy factor of 0.5, while the methanol O8 atom was refined in three positions with site occupancy factors of 1/3. The H-atoms of these water and disordered methanol molecules could neither be determined, nor fixed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray diffraction studies

For each coordination compound a suitable crystal was selected from the mother liquid and mounted to a glass fiber using the oil-drop method. Diffraction data were collected on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation). The structures were solved by direct methods. The programs collect , shelxs-97 , shelxl-97  were used for data reduction, structure solution and structure refinement, respectively. Refinement of F 2 was performed against all reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The water Hydrogen atoms of compounds 6, 9 and 10 were picked from difference maps and refined isotropically. All other H-atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. Details of compound 5: one of the two methanol molecules and the water molecule were found to be severely disordered. The methanol C7 and the water O9 were each refined with an occupancy factor of 0.5, while the methanol O8 atom was refined in three positions with site occupancy factors of 1/3. The H-atoms of these water and disordered methanol molecules could neither be determined, nor fixed.

elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data of the compounds are summarized in  . Compound 11, was found to be isomorphous with compounds 9 and 10, as deduced from infrared and X-ray powder diffraction.

Results and discussion

General observations and spectral analyses

A variety of metal salts has been reacted in alcoholic or aqueous solution with the ligand, and a (micro)crystalline, reproducible product was formed, irrespective of the used metal to ligand ratio. The so-obtained products are listed in   with their composition and with some spectral characteristics. All compounds have been characterized by common physical methods, i.e. infrared, ligand field, and C, H, N analysis. The Cu compounds were also characterized by EPR, and the Zn compound also by NMR. In 10 cases an X-ray structure determination was carried out to obtain molecular structure details (vide infra). These compounds are numbered 1-10.

elements.clean_text:
Description of the X-ray structures

The compound [CuCl2(tmtp)2] (1) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. An ortep perspective view of 1 is shown in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in  . The Cu(II) ion is in a distorted tetrahedral environment formed by two tmtp ligands and two chlorides. Such tetrahedrally distorted geometries are not uncommon for Cu(II) with N donor ligands ; a packing diagram is given in . The degree of distortion of the Cu(II) ion can be expressed by the parameter τ 4 (τ 4 =0.46 for Cu; τ 4 =0 for a square planar geometry and τ4 =1 for a tetrahedral geometry) . The Cu-N and Cu-Cl bond distances are in typical ranges for this type of [CuN2Cl2] tetrahedron, see  .

The crystal lattice of 5 contains water and MeOH molecules (of which one MeOH molecule and the water molecule are disordered); hydrogen bonds exist between the MeOH molecule and the sulfate oxygen atom and between the water and the MeOH molecules. Details are given in Table S1. A packing diagram is depicted in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>IR, Ligand field and EPR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In  selected infrared vibrations are presented. In all compounds vibrations of the ligand are easily recognized, and for the polyatomic anions also the anions are visible. The mid-IR spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are identical. In the far-IR the Cu–N vibrations are observed at 284, 246 and 248<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for 1, 2 and 3, respectively. The Cu–Cl vibration in 1 is observed at 309<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, while the Cu<ce:bold>–</ce:bold>Br vibration is observed at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. For compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the Zn–Br vibration is observed as a strong split band at 213–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. These vibrations are consistent with the literature . For the other compounds the anion vibrations are listed, i.e. for compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> the nitrate vibrations at 1270 and 798<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, other nitrate vibrations which should be visible for bonded nitrate  are obscured by ligand vibrations. The NC vibrations of NCS compounds <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> are observed at around 2051–2097<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The highest vibration is from the bidentate coordinating NCS. The IR spectra of compounds <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> are virtually identical, suggesting the same structure, the BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> vibrations of these three compounds are observed at around 1050<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. All these values are in agreement with the literature  for non-coordinated tetrafluoridoborate. The bridging sulfate anion in compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> gives four peaks at 1205, 1145, 1121 and 994<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which is according to the literature for bridging sulfate .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR, Ligand field and EPR spectroscopy

In  selected infrared vibrations are presented. In all compounds vibrations of the ligand are easily recognized, and for the polyatomic anions also the anions are visible. The mid-IR spectra of compounds 1, 2 and 3 are identical. In the far-IR the Cu-N vibrations are observed at 284, 246 and 248cm-1 for 1, 2 and 3, respectively. The Cu-Cl vibration in 1 is observed at 309cm-1, while the Cu-Br vibration is observed at 160cm-1. For compound 3 the Zn-Br vibration is observed as a strong split band at 213-200cm-1. These vibrations are consistent with the literature . For the other compounds the anion vibrations are listed, i.e. for compound 4 the nitrate vibrations at 1270 and 798cm-1, other nitrate vibrations which should be visible for bonded nitrate  are obscured by ligand vibrations. The NC vibrations of NCS compounds 6, 7 and 8 are observed at around 2051-2097cm-1. The highest vibration is from the bidentate coordinating NCS. The IR spectra of compounds 9, 10 and 11 are virtually identical, suggesting the same structure, the BF4 vibrations of these three compounds are observed at around 1050cm-1. All these values are in agreement with the literature  for non-coordinated tetrafluoridoborate. The bridging sulfate anion in compound 5 gives four peaks at 1205, 1145, 1121 and 994cm-1, which is according to the literature for bridging sulfate .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compounds containing water and/or MeOH show vibrations around 3400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in compounds, i.e. for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> a broad band (sometimes a small splitting is observed) is observed, which are attributed to the OH vibration of methanol and/or water. For coordinated water the wagging en rocking vibrations can be observed in the 700–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and the M–O vibrations around 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
. Indeed for compounds <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> in compound <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> two very broad vibrations are observed at ca. 660, 600 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, for compound <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> at around 630 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and for compound <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> at around 680, 620 and 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which is confirming the observations in the literature .</ce:para>

For coordinated water the wagging en rocking vibrations can be observed in the 700-600cm-1 and the M-O vibrations around 450cm-1 . Indeed for compounds 9, 10 and 11 in compound 9 two very broad vibrations are observed at ca. 660, 600 and 450cm-1, for compound 10 at around 630 and 450cm-1 and for compound 11 at around 680, 620 and 480cm-1, which is confirming the observations in the literature .

elements.clean_text: The powder EPR spectra of compounds 2 and 5 reveal at RT a broad isotropic band due to S =½ (around g =2.10); for compounds 1 and 4 an axial signal with g ⊥ of 2.07-2.08 and a g || of 2.24-2.26. These signals are in agreement with a     d     x   2   -   y   2       configuration for the ground state . For compound 6 a rhombic signal (g 1 =2.28, g 2 =2.11 and g 3 =2.05) is observed, which is in consistence with the five coordinated geometry of the Cu(II) ion .The ligand field transitions measured as a solid with the diffuse reflectance technique for the Cu(II) compounds (1, 2, 4, 5, 6) are observed in general as broad bands with a maximum which vary from 16.1 to 11.6×103 cm-1 with a shoulder, which vary from 13.1 to 9.1×103 cm-1. These bands are in agreement with common ligand field transitions for square-planar based geometries with a variety of distortions . Also the ligand field transitions of the Co(II) compound (9) and the Ni(II) compound (11) are in agreement with the literature for octahedral Co(II) and Ni(II) .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Concluding remarks</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The study described above on the coordination behavior of the ligand tmtp, an example of one of the several easily accessible triazolopyridimidine ligands, has shown that such ligands are versatile in their behavior. The resulting coordination compound display interesting structural and electronic properties, and in some cases interference with hydrogen bonding from solvent and to anions is seen. Fine-tuning of the formed structure appears possible by proper choice of counterions and solvents in the synthesis. Which compounds are formed as described above is difficult to determine a priori, and depends strongly on the used metal and the selected anion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Concluding remarks

The study described above on the coordination behavior of the ligand tmtp, an example of one of the several easily accessible triazolopyridimidine ligands, has shown that such ligands are versatile in their behavior. The resulting coordination compound display interesting structural and electronic properties, and in some cases interference with hydrogen bonding from solvent and to anions is seen. Fine-tuning of the formed structure appears possible by proper choice of counterions and solvents in the synthesis. Which compounds are formed as described above is difficult to determine a priori, and depends strongly on the used metal and the selected anion.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of the coordination compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The coordination compounds were prepared by the following general recipes:</ce:para><ce:para view="all">A solution of 1–2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol of the metal salt in 10–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water was added to a warm aqueous solution of the ligand (1–5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Upon standing at room temperature crystals appeared, which were collected by filtration. In some cases, MeOH/water or pure MeOH were used as a solvent. To prepare the thiocyanate compounds a metathesis reaction was used, starting from the aqueous metal nitrate and ammonium thiocyanate (1:2). Yields were found to be between 30% and 60% depending on the metal and anion. Satisfactory elemental analysis was obtained for all compounds.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the coordination compounds

The coordination compounds were prepared by the following general recipes:

A solution of 1-2mmol of the metal salt in 10-20mL water was added to a warm aqueous solution of the ligand (1-5mmol). Upon standing at room temperature crystals appeared, which were collected by filtration. In some cases, MeOH/water or pure MeOH were used as a solvent. To prepare the thiocyanate compounds a metathesis reaction was used, starting from the aqueous metal nitrate and ammonium thiocyanate (1:2). Yields were found to be between 30% and 60% depending on the metal and anion. Satisfactory elemental analysis was obtained for all compounds.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Description of the X-ray structures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The compound [CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. An ortep perspective view of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor>. The Cu(II) ion is in a distorted tetrahedral environment formed by two tmtp ligands and two chlorides. Such tetrahedrally distorted geometries are not uncommon for Cu(II) with N donor ligands ; a packing diagram is given in . The degree of distortion of the Cu(II) ion can be expressed by the parameter <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.46 for Cu; <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 for a square planar geometry and τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 for a tetrahedral geometry) . The Cu–N and Cu–Cl bond distances are in typical ranges for this type of [CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedron, see 
.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The corresponding bromide [CuBr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tmtp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Pca</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>. The unit cells contains two slightly different chromophores, but both very similar to the chloride in . An ortep perspective view of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in  and a packing figure in . Both Cu ions are in quite distorted tetrahedral environment (<ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Description of the X-ray structures

The compound [CuCl2(tmtp)2] (1) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. An ortep perspective view of 1 is shown in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in  . The Cu(II) ion is in a distorted tetrahedral environment formed by two tmtp ligands and two chlorides. Such tetrahedrally distorted geometries are not uncommon for Cu(II) with N donor ligands ; a packing diagram is given in . The degree of distortion of the Cu(II) ion can be expressed by the parameter τ 4 (τ 4 =0.46 for Cu; τ 4 =0 for a square planar geometry and τ4 =1 for a tetrahedral geometry) . The Cu-N and Cu-Cl bond distances are in typical ranges for this type of [CuN2Cl2] tetrahedron, see  .

The corresponding bromide [CuBr2(tmtp)2] (2). crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pca21. The unit cells contains two slightly different chromophores, but both very similar to the chloride in . An ortep perspective view of 2 is shown in  and a packing figure in . Both Cu ions are in quite distorted tetrahedral environment (τ 4 =0.54 for Cu; τ 4 =0 for a square planar geometry and τ 4 =1 for a tetrahedral geometry) , formed by two bromido ligands and to monodentate tmtp ligands. The Cu-N and Cu-Br bond distances are in typical ranges for this type of [CuN2Br2] tetrahedron .

The compound [ZnBr2(tmtp)2] 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. An ortep perspective view of compound 3 is depicted in  and a packing diagram is given in . In this case the distortion from tetrahedral is much smaller, as commonly seen for Zn(II) d10 ions. The Zn(II) ions are in an almost perfect tetrahedral environment (τ 4 =0.89 for Zn; τ 4 =0 for a square planar geometry and τ 4 =1 for a tetrahedral geometry) , formed by two bromido ligands and to monodentate tmtp ligands. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in . The dihedral angles of the two largest angles from which τ 4 is calculated are 116.05(8) and 118.70(2)°. The Zn-N and Zn-Br bond distances are in typical ranges for this type of [ZnN2Br2] tetrahedron .

The compound [Cu(SO4)2(tmtp)2]2(CH3OH)2⅓(H2O)1/6 (5) crystallizes in the trigonal space group   R   3   ¯    . An ortep perspective view of the dinuclear sulfate-bridged unit of 5 is presented in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in . The compound has a quite unique bis(sulfato)-bridged dinuclear structure, where each Cu(II) ion is 5-coordinated in a geometry close to tetragonal pyramidal (τ 5 =0.10; τ 5 =0 for a square pyramidal geometry and τ 5 =1 for a trigonal bipyramidal geometry; ). The sulfate is chelating to one Cu, with Cu-O distances of 1.97-1.99Å, and providing a third O atom to the other Cu(II) ion, with Cu-O=2.216(2)Å. The chelating O-Cu-O angle is 71.6(1)°. The crystal lattice of 5 contains water and MeOH molecules (of which one MeOH molecule and the water molecule are disordered); hydrogen bonds exist between the MeOH molecule and the sulfate oxygen atom and between the water and the MeOH molecules. Details are given in Table S1. A packing diagram is depicted in .

Compound 6, [Cu(H2O)(NCS)2(tmtp)2], crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and has the CuII ion is in a coordination environment which is intermediate between trigonal bipyramidal and square-pyramidal (τ 5 =0.49; τ 5 =0 for a square pyramidal geometry and τ 5 =1 for a trigonal bipyramidal geometry; ), formed by two crystallographically equivalent thiocyanate anions (nitrogen atoms N1 and N1a) and one water molecule (oxygen atom O1) in the trigonal plane, and by two symmetry-related tmtp ligands (nitrogen atoms N11 and N11a) at the apical positions. Intramolecular hydrogen bonding between the coordinated water and the non-coordinating N23 (N⋯O=2.77(1)Å is observed. The structure is depicted in  , and the packing diagram is shown in .

Compounds containing water and/or MeOH show vibrations around 3400cm-1 in compounds, i.e. for 5, 6, 9, 10 and 11 a broad band (sometimes a small splitting is observed) is observed, which are attributed to the OH vibration of methanol and/or water. For coordinated water the wagging en rocking vibrations can be observed in the 700-600cm-1 and the M-O vibrations around 450cm-1 . Indeed for compounds 9, 10 and 11 in compound 9 two very broad vibrations are observed at ca. 660, 600 and 450cm-1, for compound 10 at around 630 and 450cm-1 and for compound 11 at around 680, 620 and 480cm-1, which is confirming the observations in the literature .

cln_elements.clean_text: The powder EPR spectra of compounds 2 and 5 reveal at RT a broad isotropic band due to S =½ (around g =2.10); for compounds 1 and 4 an axial signal with g ⊥ of 2.07-2.08 and a g || of 2.24-2.26. These signals are in agreement with a     d     x   2   -   y   2       configuration for the ground state . For compound 6 a rhombic signal (g 1 =2.28, g 2 =2.11 and g 3 =2.05) is observed, which is in consistence with the five coordinated geometry of the Cu(II) ion .The ligand field transitions measured as a solid with the diffuse reflectance technique for the Cu(II) compounds (1, 2, 4, 5, 6) are observed in general as broad bands with a maximum which vary from 16.1 to 11.6×103 cm-1 with a shoulder, which vary from 13.1 to 9.1×103 cm-1. These bands are in agreement with common ligand field transitions for square-planar based geometries with a variety of distortions . Also the ligand field transitions of the Co(II) compound (9) and the Ni(II) compound (11) are in agreement with the literature for octahedral Co(II) and Ni(II) .
